fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an admissible discrete vector field on a algebraic cellular complex (C_k, d), we can generate a chain reduction. It will be computable when the cellular complex is effective.

The DVF partitions the chain groups into a direct sum C_k^{s} \oplus C_k^t \oplus C_k^c, corresponding to source, target and critical cells. We would like to create a reduction to the critical cells only. To do this, we invoke perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction and start with a simpler chain reduction.

Consider the algebraic cellular complex whose chain groups are C_k, but the differential d'( \sigma ) = \pm \tau iff \overrightharpoon { \tau \sigma } is in the vector field, and zero otherwise. The sign is determined as the sign of \tau in d( \sigma ). Hence d' : C_{k+1}^{t} \to C_k^s, and is zero otherwise. Therefore using the characterization of chain reduction as a direct sum with a split exact chain complex, we see that this complex can be reduced to the complex on C_k^p whose differential is identically zero.

Next, we try to perturb d' to d. We need h_{ \rho } \circ (d' - d) to be locally nilpotent, where \rho is the reduction constructed above. h_{ \rho } can be viewed as the inverse of d', as it maps the source cell to the target cell. Expanding the definition, we see that this map transports cells down the discrete field line. Since the vector field is admissible, such a transportation eventually terminates and it becomes zero.

Given a discrete vector field, if is admissible if the lengths of the field lines starting from a cell are bounded. In other words, we can assign a natural number to every cell such that the field lines starting from this cell have length bounded by the number. The number can be different for each cell, and can be unbounded overall.

Given a discrete vector field, the discrete version of field lines is defined as a sequence of cells alternating between degree p and (p-1) starting and ending with lower-degree cells, with a few requirements.

fr:ul.fr:li: When the degree increases, the two cells must occur as a vector in the DVF.
When the degree decreases, the degree (p-1) cell must be a (possible non-regular) face of the degree p cell.
Two degree (p-1) cells separated by a degree p cell must not be the same.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D and a perturbation \delta _C for C, we assume that h_{ \rho } \circ \delta _C is pointwise nilpotent, i.e. \forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^n (c) = 0. We can construct a new chain reduction \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D', where C' is C perturbed by \delta _C.
Note that this situation is much harder compared to , as it is generally impossible without the added condition.
For this construction using the third equivalent definition of a chain reduction in , i.e. a homotopy operator on C such that h \circ h = 0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = h.

From the informal discussion above, we can conjecture the formula h' = \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h. This reveals the reason for our pointwise nilpotency condition. With a little bit of care manipulating the infinite sum, we can prove that h' \circ h' = 0 from h \circ h = 0, and the second equation follows from a nice telescopic sum \begin {aligned} h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h \right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h \right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}

We can reconstruct the other two components of the reduction \iota _{ \rho ' } and \pi _{ \rho ' } through . In particular, D' is given by a perturbation of D. We only write down the results below for easy reference. \begin {aligned} \pi _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } ( \delta _C h_{ \rho } )^k \\ \iota _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } \delta _C ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } . \end {aligned}
The following data are equivalent.

fr:ul.fr:li: A splitting C \cong D \oplus E, where E is a split exact.
A chain homotopy h : C \to C satisfying h \circ h = 0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = h.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Substituting the requirement that h is a homotopy \operatorname {id} \to g \circ f, we get the equation d_{k+1} \circ r_k + r_{k-1} \circ d_k = \operatorname {id} , where d is the boundary operator on E_ \bullet. In other words, r is a null-homotopy of E_ \bullet, rendering it split exact. Conversely, given C \cong D \oplus E, we can reconstruct f and g as the projection and inclusion maps, with h obtained out of r in the manner depicted above.

Finally, restricting h onto D_k we see that it must be zero, since h( \operatorname {id} - p) = h - h \circ d \circ h = 0. This means that all the information of h can be reconstructed from the splitting, and thus all three sets of data are equivalent.

Given an algebraic cellular complex, suppose we can encode the basis sets C_ \bullet such that they have decidable equality, and the maps C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}] are computable, then we say the ACC is effective. Suppose further that C_ \bullet are (computably) finite sets, then we say it is effective of finite type.

Given two chain complexes C, D, a chain reduction consists of a chain map \pi : C \to D, a chain map \iota : D \to C and a chain homotopy h : \operatorname {id} \to g \circ f, such that \pi \circ \iota = \operatorname {id}, and \pi \circ h = h \circ \iota = h \circ h = 0. Here the compositions are understood to have the appropriate subscript so the degrees match.

We write the reduction as \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D. The three components are denoted \pi _{ \rho } : C \to D, \iota _{ \rho } : D \to C and h_{ \rho } : C \to C, respectively.

An algebraic cellular complex (or ACC) is a chain complex of free abelian groups. The generators are called cells, and the boundary maps can be expressed using the generators as a basis, yielding the incidence matrices.

More precisely, we may define an ACC as a sequence of sets C_ \bullet, with a sequence of functions d : C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}], such that d^2 = 0 is satisfied. When a generator has non-zero coefficient in some d \sigma, the generator is called a face of \sigma.
Note that the generators of these chain groups are canonically chosen as part of the data. So a more accurate definition is a chain complex in the Kleisli category of abelian groups.
